content:
I think there are too many "points" in the last sentence ;)
"(...) how many points points in total (...)" (?)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good to go.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Coding a solution was fun and I think it's an interesting problem. Especially in Shortest.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a nice simple problem. The idea is good, doesn't take long to solve, and shortest mode can be interesting.
P can be 0, according to constraints, what then? Also, not clear if the result will fit in an 32-bit

Please provide the size of the groups (e.g. after their number N on the first line -- it's much better to have it in some languages, even though of course for Python it does not really matter) and use it to improve the stub (e.g. "loop N loopline S pts:int").

Typos: "choosen", "seperated", "Two integer".
Edited to clarify the constraints (as it was also related to one of my previous remarks below that wasn't completely addressed).

Also, the current constraints (2 ≤ N ≤ 50, 0 < X ≤ 100) aren't completely correct (X is never explicitly defined and, assuming it's the points, we can have X = 0) and not very close to the actual data either (max N is 12 << 50, in all given cases 0 ≤ X < 10).

The new constraint 0 ≤ P ≤ 10 is incorrect: P = 0 does not make much sense (and fortunately never happens) and P goes up to 13 in the cases (in my previous message, I was assuming that X was the points attributed to each candidate, not the number of candidates, what I said then does not apply to the current P).

Also, the tests and validators do not match at all (do you actually understand the difference? because right now it feels like they should all be tests and you would need to add some corresponding validators).
